Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Type 1: Chemistry and Climate over Asia: Understanding the Impact of Changing Climate and Emissions on Atmospheric Composition (L02170219)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, supported by the joint NSF-DOE-USDA Climate Research Investment on "Decadal and Regional Climate Prediction using Earth System Models", and funded by the Division of Chemistry Special Projects Program, will develop an integrated inter-disciplinary program to focus on Asia, its climate, air quality, and impact on humans that will include connections with hydrology, ecosystems, extreme weather events, and human health. The approach is to create a team that will identify key scientific questions and develop a plan for future studies and to establish the research facilities to address chemistry and climate issues facing Asia, including the impact on humans. Analyses of the model results and satellite data will give fine-scale (10-50 km) information on connecting climate change with air quality. In turn, the air quality and climate change information will be used to estimate the vulnerability of humans to these changes.

The broader impacts of the project include providing to the science community present-day and future anthropogenic and biogenic emissions over Asia at less than 10 km resolution, a model system framework for investigating science questions addressing chemistry and climate over Asia, and a plan for future science studies as well as the training of students and postdoctoral researchers and dissemination of the research results through publications and conference presentations.

The work will advance our knowledge on the interactions of chemistry, including particles, with climate and the vulnerability of humans to these changes in Asia. The project, which is focused on one of the most highly populated and economically dynamic regions in the world, will provide a framework for detailed studies of interactions between the earth system and humans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Asia is one of the most highly populated and economically dynamic regions in the world, with much of the population located in growing mega-cities.  It is a region with significant emissions of greenhouse gases, aerosols and other pollutants, which pose high health risks to urban populations.  Emissions of these aerosols and gases increased drastically over the last decade due to economic growth and urbanization and are expected to rise further in the near future.  As such, the Asian continent plays a role in influencing climate change via its effluent of aerosols and gaseous pollutants.  Asia is also susceptible to regional changes in climate caused in part by interactions between aerosols and clouds, which potentially can have serious implications for freshwater resources. 

 

To foster collaborations between atmospheric scientists and scientists assessing the impacts of air quality and climate on agriculture, human health, and the vulnerability of various human populations, two workshops were held. The first occurred in Guangzhou, China in April 2012 addressing air quality and human health and vulnerability. The second took place in Boulder, Colorado in July 2013 and addressed the risks associated with air quality and climate on health, agriculture and water. Important outcomes of these workshops include the identification of key science questions, the development of research collaborations, and the start of focused research projects to examine specific questions. For example, an outcome from the first workshop is a project examining the impact of household burning emissions on human health in the Tibetan Plateau, which is now underway. Another outcome is an integrated study to assess the impact of ozone on crop yields in India.

 

To prepare a framework for investigating chemistry and climate in Asia, several global-scale and regional-scale model simulations have been conducted. A crucial input to these models is the amount and distribution of emissions from factories, power plants, vehicles, and residential burning. We have added an estimate of emissions from open waste (trash) burning, which has not been included in previous emissions inventories. The emissions from trash burning can contribute up to 20% or more of particulate matter emissions in Asia. We have evaluated different emission inventories with our regional-scale model. Earlier emission inventories were available at ~50 km resolution, but more recent inventories provide data at ~10 km resolution. Using these newer emission inventories produced better predictions of ozone and particulate matter in the Asian regions analyzed (South and Southeast Asia). These same emission inventories are being used by groups around the world for assessment reports on ozone and aerosols.

 

This project has established that the state-of-the-art, Weather Research and Forecasting model coupled with Chemistry is capable of simulating the meteorology and chemistry in South Asia. This model can now be used to simulate current air quality conditions and future conditions to project how air quality will change in South Asia in a changing climate. These results will be valuable for future assessment reports.

 

The project educated two graduate students and three post-doctoral researchers. They learned data analysis and numerical modeling skills, as well as built a network of colleagues and potential collaborators. Members of the project’s science team taught at several summer schools including the half-day event at our Boulder workshop.
